1. EXECUTIVE SUMMARY 68.155

InChem Corp. operates the chemical plant located at 800 Cel-River Rd., Rock Hill, SC  29730.  This plant has quantities of regulated hazardous chemicals above the EPA threshold.  InChem has a unified Risk Management Program which applies to this facility.

	1.1. Accidental release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies (a) 

InChemÂ¿s accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates technologies, procedures and management practices.  Our prevention program complies with all applicable procedures of the U.s. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) 40 CFR-68, Prevention Program. 

1.1.1. Management System (a)(I) 

InChem Corp. has a management system in place which is lead by InChemÂ¿s President, who oversees the implementation and on-going use of the RMP elements.  This program, along with plant specific policies, eliminates and or reduces the likelihood of a hazardous chemical release at the plant. 

1.1.2. Prevention Program Level 3 (a)(2) 

InChem Corp. maintains policies, procedures and systems as part of their prevention program.  These are applied to the entire facility plus RMP elements needed to implement the program, and the like elements in the plants OSHA PSM program.

1.2. InChem Corp. Source and Regulated Substances Handled at the Rock Hill Site (b) 

InChem Corp. employs 65 full-time employees engaged in plant and administrative operations.  Epichlorohydrin is used in the plantÂ¿s operations.

1.2.1.Site Description (b)(1) 

The site is owned and operated by InChem Corp.  The site is located at 800 Cel-River Rd., Rock Hill, SC  29730.  The site is boardered by Cherry Road on the west, Cel-River Rd. on the South, Greens of Rock Hill on the North, and Eden Terrace Extension on the East.

The Plant includes an epichlorohydrin storage and charging system contained in specially designed storage vessels and ancillary equipment within the processing building.  The boun

daries of the system subject to the RMP regulation includes the Epichlorohydrin Bulk Storage Tank and process feed system.

These are detailed in the Process and Instrument Drawings (P&ID) which are part of the plant Process Safety Information (PSI).

1.2.2. Regulated Substances (b)(2) 

Epichlorohydrin is the regulated substances on site which exceeds the EPA 40 CFR-68 rule threshold quantity.


The Epichlorohydrin process was istalled as part of the process for manufacturing Phenoxy Resin.  It operates under permit from the State of South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control (SC DHEC).  The epichlorohydrin is received in railcars or tankers containers which are unloaded upon arrival at the site into our Epichlorohydrin Bulk Storage Tank.


Epichlorohydrin is an EPA toxic chemical.  It is an irritant, flammable and it is corrosive.  Epichlorohydrin is liquid with the formula C3H5ClO.  It has a 10 ppm OSHA ceiling Permissible Exposure Limit (PEL) and an NFPA health rating of 3; with acute health hazards and fire hazards.

1.4. Accidental Release Prevention Program (d) 

InChemÂ¿s accidental release prevention program is based on OSHA's PSM program and EPA's RMP Level 3 prevention program.  The PSM program has been in place and effectively used.  It is part of the plants operating culture.

1.4.1. General Accidental release Prevention Program (d)(I) 

Plant-wide, many elements of the prevention program are used for all operations. The overviews of these programs are listed below: 

InChem has detailed process safety information on each of its operations. 

Training is the backbone of employee knowledge, job operations and is ongoing in each area.  Employee training in operations and maintenance emphasizes awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of all chemicals used. 

Maintenance and preventive maintenance are used for all operations, making mechanical

ipment.  These materials are made of carbon or stainless steel with epichlorohydrin compatible gasketing materials.  The maximum pressure the epichlorohydrin system should see at any given time is limited to 150 psig and dictated by the pump pressure.  Pressure relief valves ensure any releases return back into the system.

1.5. Five-Year Accident History (e) 

InChem Corp. has had no accidental releases of epichlorohydrin in the past five years per EPA 40 CFR 68.42 (a).  All accidents resulting in death, injury, significant property damage resulting from a release from a covered process are reported according to EPA 40 CFR 68.42 (a).

1.6. Emergency Response Program (1) 

Emergency response procedures are contained in the InChem Corp. Contingency Plan (Emergency Response Plan).  The plan includes an emergency response decision tree and a notification plan.  The Plant also has site-specific emergency actions defined in the plants operating procedures.  Emergency response drills and drill evaluations are conducted annually by the senior staff.  Emergency operation and response procedures are also reviewed at that time.

Besides the specific emergency response program, key elements of the prevention programs are incorporated in the operating culture of InChem Corp.

The Contingency Plan procedures detail the actions and responses to spills (releases). The plan includes training of all plant operators.  The primary response team includes the local fire department and rescue, plus the HazMat Team (all off site).  All of these respond to severe leak situations.  Actions include catastrophic, severe, and moderate leaks.

If a reportable quantity release of an RMP covered chemical occurs, the National Response Center is contacted at 800-424-8802.  For Epichlorohydrin this is 100 lbs. 

1.6.1. Personnel (f)(I) 

Personnel are the key resource of InChemÂ¿s prevention program.  Our employees make up the operators and incident commanders.  InChem Corp. fosters a high level o

f involvement in every aspect of the epichlorohydrin system operations including participation in:
Safety teams,
Development of the operation procedures,
Hazard evaluations, and,
on-going training of the operators and other involved staff.

1.7. Changes to Improve Safety (g) 

Changes to improve safety (recommended actions) were identified in theDecember 2008, internal safety HazOp, tour, and audit of the PSM program.  These recommended actions have now been evaluated and implementation is underway.  An Audit was conducted to review the PSM program.

InChem Corp. continually reviews implemented and potential safety improvements for all of its operations.  Currently, the InChem Corp. management team and process safety team are reviewing potential upgrades to the existing design of the operations to make the system even safer to prevent a release and minimize consequences in the event of a release of epichlorohydrin.
